instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> One wire ok, no power. Nothing past <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Customer board had a blown backlight fuse. Couple weeks later the board is back and not powering on at all.


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 3.325
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>: 5.02
<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>: 0.431

<CAPACITOR>C7841</CAPACITOR>: 4.89v
<RESISTOR>R7842</RESISTOR>: 5.02

<CAPACITOR>C7840</CAPACITOR>::Pin1 5.02v
<CAPACITOR>C7840</CAPACITOR>::Pin2 4.89v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> One wire ok, no power. Nothing past <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is created by a chip that is powered by <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - it steps down <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>'s 12.6v to 5v.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.3v on your board. But you say <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is 5v. 

?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> One wire ok, no power. Nothing past <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Sorry, I miss read my notes!

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is indeed 12.6
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is 3.325

I really need to tidy up my notes when I write them down.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> One wire ok, no power. Nothing past <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>  is 3.325 volts thats close inuf. 
Keep going. 
First s5 rails partly there. 
Second s3 rails. 
Third s0 rails.

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> One wire ok, no power. Nothing past <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>.
threads.message: The backlit fuse did not just pop for no reason. This must have been liquid spill. Corrosion under SMC/clock chip?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> One wire ok, no power. Nothing past <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
No evidence of liquid, but the board was pretty dusty so may have been humidity.

SMC area looks pretty clean and tidy.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> One wire ok, no power. Nothing past <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>.
threads.message: Backlight fuse still good now? Could be a short in the LCD cable and that could short out BKL to any bus that is connected to the LCD. Check RTC stuff and shorts on all rails.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> One wire ok, no power. Nothing past <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
Backlight is OK now.

The system won't boot up and <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL> is around 0.430v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> One wire ok, no power. Nothing past <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>.
threads.message:
[USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER] Any suggestions on where to measure from here?

I have a few of boards with missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL> now.

threads.message: 1.5V at DSW is no good. Usually SMC related, I bet there is crap under it.

threads.message:
Thanks Duke.
What are my options for sorting out the problem? I seem to get a large amount of SMC issues.
